title: EU consumer group wants to ban carbon-neutral claims - Food Business News
summary: The European consumer organization BEUC is calling for a ban on carbon-neutral claims for products, arguing they are misleading and inaccurate. The group criticizes the practice of carbon offsetting, which allows companies to compensate for their emissions by funding projects that reduce emissions elsewhere. The BEUC argues that these claims are greenwashing and that companies should prioritize reducing their own emissions.

title: Wyke Farms carbon-neutral Aged English Cheddar expands availability in U.S. - dairyfoods.com
summary: Wyke Farms, a 162-year-old English cheesemaker, has expanded U.S. availability of its Ivy’s Reserve Vintage Cheddar, which is marketed as the "world’s first carbon-neutral Aged English Cheddar."  The cheese is aged up to 18 months and is made from milk from the company's own grass-grazing herds, with a suggested retail price between $9.99 and $10.99 for a 7-ounce brick.

title: Hanon Systems Commits to Science-Based Targets Initiative (SBTi) - PR Newswire
summary: Hanon Systems, a global automotive thermal and energy management solutions provider, has joined the Business Ambition for 1.5°C campaign to reduce its carbon footprint. The company has committed to setting science-based emissions reduction targets in line with the Paris Agreement, aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2040. Hanon Systems is implementing various strategies to achieve this goal, including developing low-carbon products and solutions, educating employees, and partnering with suppliers to source low-carbon materials.
product_or_process: Low-carbon variants of existing products and new low-carbon solutions

title: EU urged to ban 'carbon neutral' claims for food and drink: 'There's no such thing as a CO2 neutral banana' - FoodNavigator.com
summary: The European Consumer Organisation (BEUC) calls for a ban on carbon neutral claims on food and drink products, arguing that the claims are misleading and scientifically inaccurate.  The Carbon Trust, which certifies carbon neutral claims, acknowledges that almost all food and drink production will involve some carbon emissions, but maintains that carbon neutrality is a well-defined term with a well-publicized methodology. BEUC contends that carbon offsetting, which underpins most carbon neutral claims, does not guarantee the 'locking in' of carbon for the future and that relying on offsetting delays genuine efforts to reduce emissions.
likely_naics_codes: ['541910 - Marketing Consulting Services', '541611 - Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services', '541613 - Environmental Consulting Services', '541614 -  Management, Scientific, and Technical Consulting Services']
greenwashing: The article suggests that carbon neutral claims on food and drink products may be a form of greenwashing, misleading consumers into believing that the products are environmentally friendly when they may not be.

title: Multi X launches 100% carbon-neutral certified salmon - Aquafeed.com

Multi X is committed to sustainable practices and aims to achieve carbon neutrality across its product lines by 2030.

title: How sustainable are your running shoes? - Runner's World UK
summary: The running shoe industry is facing scrutiny for its environmental impact, with critics arguing that current sustainability efforts are insufficient. While some companies are making strides with recycled materials and renewable energy, true sustainability requires a shift towards renewable materials and a closed-loop economy. Consumers can play a role by buying fewer shoes and choosing durable, repairable options.
